elements.text: if I'm given a list of grammar rules like: (

text: Can we cross post this publicly to <https://discourse.julialang.org|Discourse> for further visibility? React with :bridge: on the message above to approve. <https://github.com/JuliaCommunity/SlackBridge/blob/main/README.md#faq|More info here>

Success, it has been cross posted <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/55632| to Discourse>. Keep and eye out on Discourse for responses and please add an answer there once you are satisfied with the solution so others can benefit as well. Happy debugging!
If the grammar can be modelled by a finite state machine, use Automa.jl. I don't know of a similar package for other kinds of grammars

elements.text: If the grammar can be modelled by a finite state machine, use Automa.jl. I don't know of a similar package for other kinds of grammars

text:
thanks! i have a very basic understanding of FSMs... where can i read about this to figure out if the rules can be modeled by FSM?
this snippet makes me think it can be
```Every file consists of a series of lines that start with a keyword followed by numbers, names, and formulas or declare a named formula such as a differential equation or auxiliary quantity. Only the first letter of the keyword is important; e.g. the parser treats "parameter" and "punxatawney" exactly the same.```

text: I think that if you can write down the grammer without any rule referring to itself, or without having circular references, then you can

text: Like JSON, for example, where an array can be inside an array.

text: That means you can't, in the grammar of JSON, define "array" without including "array" in the definition
